citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
* The last recorded scheduled visit by the attending veterinarian for 21 Bison was on 05/16/22. Regularly scheduled visits
are important to determine if all aspects of animal care (nutrition, health, environment, water, and air quality, etc.) are
being provided. Each exhibitor must have regularly scheduled visits to the premise of the exhibitor. Correct by 10/21/23.

* Official USDA form 7019 (Record of Animals on Hand other then Cats or Dogs) had nine Elk recorded but there were 15
Adult Elk counted by the inspector. When the records and Elk currently at the facility do not match it makes the records
incomplete. Missing, incomplete, or inaccurate records impede in the inspection process and makes animal tracking
difficult to impossible. Complete and accurate records are needed to ensure each animal’s identity can be known with
certainty. In addition, complete and accurate records are essential for tracking the movement of animals and to facilitate
the inspection process. The exhibitor must maintain complete and accurate records of all Elk at all times. Correct by
10/21/23.

* There are six Elk listed on the Aphis form 7019 (Records of Animals on hand other then Dogs or Cats) that do not have
complete and required information for the entry under from whom the elk were acquired from. Complete and accurate
records are needed to ensure each animal’s identity can be known with certainty and to facilitate the ability to trace the
elk. This information must be included for the records to be considered accurate and complete. The exhibitor must
maintain records which fully disclose all information concerning each elk in their possession. Correct by 10/21/23.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative.
n

narrative:
2.40(a)(1) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
* The last recorded scheduled visit by the attending veterinarian for 21 Bison was on 05/16/22. Regularly scheduled visits 
are important to determine if all aspects of animal care (nutrition, health, environment, water, and air quality, etc.) are 
being provided. Each exhibitor must have regularly scheduled visits to the premise of the exhibitor. Correct by 10/21/23. 
2.75(b)(1) 
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
* Official USDA form 7019 (Record of Animals on Hand other then Cats or Dogs) had nine Elk recorded but there were 15 
Adult Elk counted by the inspector. When the records and Elk currently at the facility do not match it makes the records 
incomplete. Missing, incomplete, or inaccurate records impede in the inspection process and makes animal tracking 
difficult to impossible. Complete and accurate records are needed to ensure each animal’s identity can be known with 
certainty. In addition, complete and accurate records are essential for tracking the movement of animals and to facilitate 
the inspection process. The exhibitor must maintain complete and accurate records of all Elk at all times. Correct by 
10/21/23. 
2.75(b)(1)(i) 
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
* There are six Elk listed on the Aphis form 7019 (Records of Animals on hand other then Dogs or Cats) that do not have 
complete and required information for the entry under from whom the elk were acquired from. Complete and accurate 
records are needed to ensure each animal’s identity can be known with certainty and to facilitate the ability to trace the 
elk. This information must be included for the records to be considered accurate and complete. The exhibitor must 
maintain records which fully disclose all information concerning each elk in their possession. Correct by 10/21/23. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative. 
 
 n
